column2: Which is the more usual form?
column3: I can't get onto the roof. {{c1::I don't have a ladder.}}
column4: I don't have a ladder. / I haven't a ladder.

column2: Which is the more usual form?
column3: He can't get into the house. {{c1::He hasn't got a key.}}
column4: He hasn't got a key. / He hasn't a key.

column2: Which is the more usual form?
column3: I was very busy yesterday. {{c1::I didn't have time to do the shopping.}}
column4: I hadn't time to do the shopping. / I didn't have time to do the shopping.

column2: Which is the more usual form?
column3:
A: .......... {{c1::Have you got your phone?}}
B: No, I forgot to bring it.
column4: Have you got your phone? / Have you your phone?

column2: Which is the more usual form?
column3:
A: .......... {{c1::Does Jack have a job?}}
B: Yes, he works at the hospital.
column4: Has Jack a job? / Does Jack have a job?

column2: Which is the more usual form?
column3: When you worked in your last job, {{c1::did you have your own office?}}
column4: had you your own office? / did you have your own office?

column2: Which is the more usual form?
column3:
{{c1::Jack doesn't have a car.}}
He can't drive.
column4: Jack doesn't have a car. / Jack hasn't a car.

column2: Which is the more usual form?
column3: We got wet in the rain. {{c1::We didn't have an umbrella.}}
column4: We didn't have an umbrella. / We hadn't an umbrella.

column2: Which is the more usual form?
column3:
A: Where's the key?
B: .......... {{c1::I don't know. I haven't got it.}}
column4: I don't know. I haven't it. / I don't know. I haven't got it.

column2: Which is the more usual form?
column3:
A: .......... {{c1::Tom had a motorbike, didn't he?}}
B: Yes, that's right.
column4: Tom had a motorbike, hadn't he? / Tom had a motorbike, didn't he?
